title: CEO demands employee work from office after a 2-second cameo of his 5-year-old daughter on a call, leads to his resignation: ‘She stood up and looked over my shoulder. She didn't make any noise’
description: Remember when we thought remote work would solve all our problems? No more commutes, no more office politics, just peaceful productivity in our pajamas. Oh, sweet summer children, how naive we were! While working from home has liberated us from fluorescent lighting and mysterious break room odors, it's created an entirely new circus of corporate absurdities.We're all living in this bizarre new world where our homes have become fishbowls, broadcasted to colleagues through the unforgiving eye of webcams. Suddenly, everyone's a critic of your bookshelves, your choice of virtual background, or just exposed to that questionable art piece your mother-in-law gifted you that's now visible unfortunately.Some companies have apparently developed policies more complex than international trade agreements about what can and cannot appear in your sacred two-foot-square Zoom rectangle, Or the unwritten rules about what constitutes a "professional" home office environment.Which leads me to today's story corporate acrobat: a dedicated employee who committed the unthinkable crime of allowing his five-year-old daughter to briefly exist in the same space as a late-night video call.
author: Etai Eshet

html:
Remember when we thought remote work would solve all our problems? No more commutes, no more office politics, just peaceful productivity in our pajamas. Oh, sweet summer children, how naive we were! While working from home has liberated us from fluorescent lighting and mysterious break room odors, it's created an entirely new circus of corporate absurdities.

We're all living in this bizarre new world where our homes have become fishbowls, broadcasted to colleagues through the unforgiving eye of webcams. Suddenly, everyone's a critic of your bookshelves, your choice of virtual background, or just exposed to that questionable art piece your mother-in-law gifted you that's now visible unfortunately.

Some companies have apparently developed policies more complex than international trade agreements about what can and cannot appear in your sacred two-foot-square Zoom rectangle, Or the unwritten rules about what constitutes a "professional" home office environment.

Which leads me to today's story corporate acrobat: a dedicated employee who committed the unthinkable crime of allowing his five-year-old daughter to briefly exist in the same space as a late-night video call.
